title: Developmental Domain 2: Physical Development and Health
subject: Early Learning Guidelines: Birth to Age 3 (2012-)

document.title: Illinois Early Learning Guidelines For Children Birth to Age Three

F6F407EDD44346C1A7C8569CC82AD8E8.description: Attempts to put on shoes and socks without help

C0441FC3F8214A829A4DE00E23B43775.description:
Begins to demonstrate an interest in using the bathroom, e.g.,
wants to sit on “potty”

A9DC74BBDE2B4C5286F4A92FA5E2FDBF.description: Uses nonverbal and/or verbal communication to specify needs

85AFB0B74B8A4E4AA5868035C66C4204.description: Makes choices pertaining to dressing and eating

FEA617B1909146F6BBB64DF7884E0178.description: Performs some self-care tasks regularly and mostly independently, e.g., brushes teeth, washes hands, places cup in sink

5505630CB7CA4C3B9FB851DFC949695F.description: Undresses independently but still needs assistance with dressing

32C32109FAAF40E48085625AB46E5DEB.description: Attempts to brush teeth with support

CB58AF67BD8641ACB2FD5F6555E993C2.description: Starts to indicate needs with gestures or a word, e.g., tugs diaper when wet, says “milk” when thirsty

FB1A8A607DB84048ADD53BAFC5DD0E86.description: Improves ability to calm self, may fall asleep on own

60B03E5ACC394B9B9E3252665E6856A7.description: Feeds self with foods that he or she can pick up

243ACEE8C0874DDBB7CA5BA6A28259CE.description: Shakes head to demonstrate no; pushes objects away

93507848B33C425680802A6223691BCE.description: Grasps and drinks from a cup

5771548D0CCF44C697FC9B2C4EB8BCFC.description: Attempts to feed self with a bottle

F5AC49B794704B1698FB14DCC307DC4E.description: Starts to develop self-soothing skills, e.g., sucks fingers for comfort and regulation

026A6155478C4A70996A5BA21D5D54BD.description:
Signals to indicate needs, e.g., cries when hungry, arches back
when in pain or uncomfortable, turns head to disengage from
object or person

98695612038C44858CCC217CA9869EB0.description: Children demonstrate the desire and ability to participate in and practice self-care routines.

24D650F79F7D4C289B75CCB4D0958C79.description:
Perceives and acts accordingly when holding a fragile object,
both in the actual environment and in play, e.g., walks carefully
when holding a pretend tea cup

D8AAC3B43DA048A489932FDC4DA04D41.description:
Adjusts approach to unknown objects, e.g., presses harder on a
lump of clay

CF37380EBE804EBB8BF100678DE20CE6.description: Imitates familiar adults when coloring; draws lines and/or circles

6A2E5BD322F24911B8A76E720A736BAA.description:
Adjusts approach to environment, e.g., changes volume of voice
to adjust to noise level in the environment

9B0B3BD847D349E0A0A2449DAB8B6DFC.description:
Recognizes situations that need to be approached cautiously,
e.g., walks slowly with a cup of water, or with food on a plate

61FCB03833414BCC99F1A002095B5F38.description: Enjoys physical play, e.g., wrestling, tickling

6730B0629D6D4A51A24491B26A607991.description:
Plays with water and sand tables; explores by pouring, digging,
and filling

109CAF1FE7C74D09856E2EEAB031B0D3.description:
Adjusts manner of walking depending on the surface, e.g., walks
carefully across gravel

ABAF634D01604703B46A38F83E23EAC9.description:
Becomes aware of obstacles in the environment, e.g., crawls
around the table to get the ball

6219DEB01CD94C3EBE43D98BE45A2CD3.description:
Begins to show a preference for or aversion to particular sensory activities, e.g., pulls hand away from unfamiliar objects or
unpleasant textures

534141E04DEA493498B972A26FA74D0C.description:
Begins to manipulate materials, e.g., pounds at play dough,
squeezes finger foods

6689874AD6824F138F483A2E0EEAC07D.description: Recognizes familiar objects and begins to demonstrate favoritism for certain toys

4F340D3F76974E978616A40FD4EA49B5.description: Feels the sensation of being touched and looks around to identify the source of the touch, e.g., person or object

611EE3D1C1B74C44BA49A1AAFA12D20B.description:
Has a range of vision that extends to several feet, which in turn
leads to seeing colors and seeing objects from a distance

4A1649B572D245658BE9EABB43BCB517.description: Attempts to mimic sounds heard in the environment

17465E2474904D7A91C3DDF4431E0E2B.description: Explores objects through senses, e.g., mouths, touches objects

1C0F4A5EA8364312A2AD405152BACAFA.description:
Responds to changes in the environment, e.g., startles when
hearing a loud noise, turns head toward light

70AB66518638403BBB312D2D7C712D22.description: Children demonstrate the ability to distinguish, process, and respond to sensory stimuli in their environment.

161FC3590AE645D2B056FAEE548D7A23.description:
Uses hand-eye coordination in a more controlled manner, e.g.,
completes puzzles, strings beads together

30AB53C47ED841B996B3AC03E0FE3573.description: Scribbles with intent and begins to draw circles and lines on own

BD4CDB9E5AF542F9AEEC16E6FF64C675.description:
Attempts to help with dressing self, e.g., snaps buttons, pulls
zipper, puts socks and shoes on

3CB3CEAAB73B496A9479336F47CDAD61.description: Begins to use more complicated hand movements, e.g., uses eating utensils independently, stacks blocks

0A5E1D57FAE34E4D81BA5BB349989E22.description:
Controls placement of objects in a more effective manner, e.g.,
stacks blocks in a more orderly fashion

45579CA2ECF8478DAD24EB61B2722E54.description: Begins to imitate lines and circles when drawing

1B4A9B8D305146F2821371BDF340DD73.description:
Uses simple tools, e.g., scooper to scoop sand or water, crayon
for scribbling

B71D68FF88AF46758D01CC955513D501.description:
Uses baby sign to communicate various concepts, e.g., “all
done,” “more,” “water”

C73AC791118F4616AB054B9FC43BDC48.description:
Attempts to fold various types of materials, e.g., paper, baby
blanket

6B650598CC5B40C1ADA547158F3F7F71.description: Participates in finger plays, e.g., moves hands to imitate caregiver’s hands when singing “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”

AAA294267AAD462BB24599D6B6A50027.description:
Coordinates increasingly complex hand movements to manipulate objects, e.g., crumples paper, connects and disconnects toy
links, flips light switch on and off

AC75B47F11CC473E8FF19964FC27664C.description:
Uses hands in a purposeful manner, e.g., turns the pages of a
board book, drops objects into a bucket

D755905AB3AF4D0AADE2303BA7520B40.description: Begins to use simple baby signs (if exposed to baby sign language), e.g., moves hands toward each other to signal more

1BDF9CA942614E92891C2CD310635523.description: Uses pincer grasp, e.g., picks up a Cheerio with thumb and forefinger

0B697E884918473BBCDC90700B71516B.description: Holds a small object in each hand; bangs them together

5EC50863115E4E22B3784EECBCD437D7.description:
Uses raking motion with hands to bring objects closer, e.g., uses
all fingers to bring small objects closer to body

9BF3E59A23F0472A8B2EE0E5F1A22F1F.description: Transfers an object from one hand to the other

5CCF6340BF2F467EBE746794E6FF3A96.description: Opens hands when in a relaxed state

9BE27DEFEB104B68B18EFBAA2BB1AF5A.description: Children demonstrate the ability to coordinate their small muscles in order to move and control objects.

CCC121AF8BB84CF283FCE0A4BB11C817.description: Pedals a tricycle with both feet

5C92E5FFBAAC46B5A0443115638FAEB8.description: Walks on tiptoes, walks backward, and runs

FD9871C69BBE40EC843F808AE7EE93C0.description: Walks up and down the stairs by placing both feet on each step

A73996697F78402A86212A0D0808F302.description: Jumps forward a few inches; jumps from slightly elevated surface onto the ground

A8443E80DE2A476487C663411BD6609E.description:
Stands on one foot with support and maintains balance for a
brief period of time

B15C5F06A2D6475486012F3458FD72A9.description: Rides a toy by using his or her hands or feet

FB1F8E0AC3AF4773B38B0EE56B67B82F.description: Kicks and attempts to catch a ball

797B1A6030934C35A2154E06F0B593A5.description:
Holds objects or toys while walking, e.g., pulls a car by a string
while walking around the room

8D99BFC995C348CEB2608D0851BFDCAA.description:
Attempts to climb objects, e.g., furniture, steps, simple climbing
structures

0AD6AF01FFC240FB84AA3CDF7E846238.description: Gets into a standing position without support

9EBDE0702256496FA0BEF8EC7971773A.description: Briefly maintains balance when placed in a non-supported standing position

368D32C7265E4BC084F8256A90292EB8.description:
Cruises while holding on to furniture, e.g., walks around crib,
holding on to railing

248E918174E84CF5912D06373055D956.description:
Moves objects with large muscles, e.g., pushes a toy car with
legs, rolls a ball

FA7FCBD5EC0D4E919CEA01219620B8CB.description: Pulls to a stand using help from furniture or caregiver

5F622799B9A849A58816500F3C00982E.description: Crawls from one point to another

12177EF93F144A65B4880DA9C772FF93.description: Rocks back and forth on knees

8192D2933A0B4A72B6DD2DE63DAF5C3F.description: Moves from hands and knees to a sitting position

B0323D5D7DAF4081B6A9CA84454FF962.description: Scoots body to attempt to move from one point to another

142FF7ADEB8542C186C2CC63EAB37784.description: Begins to gain balance, e.g., sits with and without support

A209B86D7AA9485B86B6D6E8CC320EF1.description: Brings both hands to midline, i.e., center of the body

AC3989C3632B43EC9BCE0C6241CA8185.description: Rolls from back to stomach and from stomach to back

88FD8F8A6E4A4BFD9B88DCCDAF0BD87F.description: Brings feet to mouth while lying on back

3B6DBF14138D42D996D60005A047738B.description: Children demonstrate strength, coordination, and controlled use of large muscles .
